instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A that came to me two weeks ago with no power, that had one CD315 burnt. I replaced the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, and the mac started working again, with no other problem.

Then, after a few days, the client reported that the mac stoped charging the battery, and now it doesn't power on at all. The metter only shows 5V, on all ports, and the ampmeter doesn't reboot on any port (steady 5V on all ports).

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Which voltages do you get on the board?
Did you check any signal from power on sequence?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
HI,
I didn't check the power on sequence, but on the fuses I get 5V.
I thought that maybe it was already a known problem... I'll measure them

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
There could be several reasons to get it stuck in 5V input.
We need some readings from the board...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
You're right. Sorry

F3000 = 5V both pins

I stopped here (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) because i don't understand those measures, and don't know exactly what to do next :

On two ports I get:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> =  oscillates between 7 and 11V

And on the other 2 ports I get
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = = 3.2V

I get different values on several rails, depending on witch port i connect the power

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
If you get different behaviour, depending which USB-C port is powered on, then you have a problem on the USB-C area.
Try to reflow, or change again that <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I've replaced the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, but the problem remains the same.  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with the same measurements than before

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: So, still not same behaviour on all USB-C ports?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Yes, still differente values deppending on the port powered on.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  has 3.1V or 7~11 deppending on the port connected

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: What about <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
On  <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>  I have 0V on all 4 pads.
But now, the metter reboots on 3 ports. I suppose that  the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> controlling the port that has steady 5V, is the one causing the problem. Correct? How can I be sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
In theory that port has problems.
But you should get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> requires at least 5V input.
Check diode mode to ground there.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Diode on  <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is OK (0,507V) on all pads.
when connected on the ports that reboots the metter, i get 0.3 ~0.5V on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>  <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Did you properly measure voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Use <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR> as test point.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: Yes, on <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR>, the values are the same (diode and voltage), with the difference that the voltage oscilates a bit higher (0.3 ~0.9V), and one time it reached (very, very  quickly 2V and then continuated to oscilate from 0.3 to 0.7V))

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Then you have a common problem for all USB-C ports; at least one should get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
Check all input fuses, near <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: I didn't measured <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> with all USB-C ports. Only with one that is rebooting the metter. Shall i measure <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on all ports connected? On the fuses i get 0~5V (rebooting) and steady 5V on the steady port.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> with each USB-C port powered.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: The measures are the same on all ports, except when connected to the steady 5V port. On that one, i get 0V (0.0003V)on all pads of <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
"The measures are the same on all ports"
Yeah, but 0V, or 5V on these 3 ports?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message: On each of those 3 ports (rebooting ones), the voltages oscilates between 0.3V and 0.9V, and one time it reached (very, very quickly 2V and then continuated to oscilate from 0.3V to 0.9V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
You still have problems on USB-C areas.
Check diode mode to ground on all LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.535V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.496V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> =  0.538V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.520V

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.540V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.504V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> =  0.544V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.521V

UB300:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.529V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.0671V

I think that the short is here. Shall I remove UB300?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
1V8 LDOD is very low on UB300, change the chip.
Don't forget to check UB400 at the end too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-010-41-A no power
threads.message:
Sorry for the delay, but I had a flood in the store and this has been very difficult. I only replaced it today, and It turned out, it was the  UB300  damaged.
It's working again.
Thanks!
